metadata.titleEn: A dense station-based long-term and high-accuracy dataset of daily surface solar radiation in China
metadata.description: The lack of long-term and high-quality solar radiation data has been an obstacle for scientific and industrial fields. In this study, a dense station-based long-term and high-accuracy dataset of daily surface solar radiation was developed with two surface radiation models. One is the model developed by Yang et al. (2006) for global radiation estimate, and the other is the model developed by Tang et al. (2018) for direct radiation estimate. The main inputs for developing the dataset are surface pressure, air temperature, relative humidity, horizontal visibility, and sunshine duration, which are the routine meteorological variables observed at the 2743 China Meteorological Administration (CMA) weather stations. Validation against in-situ observations and comparisons with two satellite-based radiation products show that our station-based radiation dataset clearly outperforms the satellite-based radiation products at both daily and monthly scales. In addition, our dataset is available for more than 60 years and includes three radiation components of global, direct and diffuse radiation, which is not possible with satellite products. This station-based radiation dataset will contribute to the climate change research and solar energy engineering applications in the future.
metadata.instructions: File name: the data set contains 2474 files, including station. txt file mainly describe the information on the site of 2473, corresponding to each column: longitude, latitude and elevation; and 2473 files of 2473 stations data (for example: 50136 rad. daily. txt)， corresponding to each column  on the data of 2473: year, month, day and global radiation, direct radiation and diffuse radiation.Data read method: the data set all of the ASCII file can be directly opened by text program (like notepad).

background: Solar radiation provides energy to everything on Earth; drives the water, energy and carbon cycles of the Earth’s climate system; and largely determines the climatic conditions of human habitats (Wild, 2009). Solar radiation information at the Earth’s surface is crucial in research of agriculture, hydrology, ecology and climate change and in simulations of land surface processes (Wang et al., 2012). Global radiation is an important component of the surface energy budgets (Wild et al., 2015), and accurate global radiation data will contribute to the simulation of land-surface-related processes, such as ecological, hydrological, agricultural and glacial simulations (Tang et al., 2019b). Due to its multi-directional nature, diffuse radiation penetrates the vegetation canopy more than direct radiation, and more diffuse radiation can increase the light energy use efficiency of the canopy (Mercado et al., 2009; Yang et al., 2019). In situ measurements are considered to be the most effective and direct means of obtaining surface solar radiation data. However, the number of radiation observation stations is very low due to high maintenance and calibration costs. Therefore, the lack of long-term and dense solar radiation observations has become a tough challenge. Satellites can provide continuous spatiotemporal observations, and retrieval based on satellite remote sensing is considered to be one of the most effective and commonly used means to fill the gap in ground-based radiation measurements (Lu et al., 2011; Zhang et al., 2014; Huang et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2020; Letu et al., 2021).
research objective: In this study, a dense station-based, long-term and high-accuracy dataset of daily surface solar radiation was developed using two surface radiation models. This station-based radiation dataset will contribute to the climate change research and solar energy engineering applications in the future. Therefore, these two hybrid models provide us with an opportunity to construct daily surface solar radiation at routine weather stations once the observations of meteorological variables are available. The constructed dataset will contribute to simulations of land surface processes, climate change analysis and solar energy applications. This long-term dataset will contribute to the analysis of long-term variations in surface process simulations and solar energy applications, such as the assessment of solar energy potential, the determination of the optimal angle for solar PV panels and their long-term variation analysis, as well as the assessment of historical extreme events in solar energy systems.
challenges: Another issue is that the radiation observation stations are very unevenly distributed, with most of radiation stations being located in flat and densely populated areas and with a very small number of stations being located in complex-terrain areas and sparsely populated areas. In addition, radiation measurements are considered to be more prone to problems and unreliable data than those of other meteorological variables. For example, erroneous or spurious data were frequently found in the CMA radiation observations (Shi et al., 2008; Tang et al., 2011). Therefore, the lack of long-term and dense solar radiation observations has become a tough challenge. First, the time series of satellite radiation products are generally not long enough to meet the demand for long-time-series data, such as for climate change studies. Second, the updating of satellite sensors and the fusion of multi-source satellites would lead to inconsistent data quality and introduce large uncertainties into the analysis of long-term variations (Feng and Wang, 2021a; Shao et al., 2022). Third, most satellite radiation products only provide global radiation but do not include direct and diffuse radiation because the uncertainty in algorithms for estimating direct and diffuse radiation is much larger than the uncertainty in global radiation.
methods: In this study, daily global radiation and daily direct radiation were estimated using the hybrid model of Yang et al. (2006) and the method developed by Tang et al. (2018). Finally, daily diffuse radiation was calculated by subtracting direct radiation from global radiation. The methods for estimating daily global, direct and diffuse radiation can be simply described by the following five mathematical formulas: Rg =(Rb,clr +Rd,clr)τc,g, (1) Rb =Rb,clrτc,b, (2) Rd =Rg −Rb, (3) τc,g =0.2505 +1.1468(n/N)−0.3974(n/N)2, (4) τc,b =0.4868(n/N)+0.5132(n/N)2, (5). The overall flowchart for the estimation of the station-based radiation products is shown in Fig. 1, which consists mainly of input, model and output sections.
dataset: The main inputs for the development of the dataset are surface pressure, air temperature, relative humidity, horizontal visibility and sunshine duration, which are the routine meteorological variables observed at the 2743 China Meteorological Administration (CMA) weather stations. Finally, in this study, a dataset of more than 60 years of daily global, direct and diffuse radiation was constructed using the methods described above at the 2473 CMA routine meteorological stations from the 1950s to 2021, with most stations covering the period of 1961–2021.
findings: Validation against in situ observations and comparisons with two satellite-based radiation products shows that our station-based radiation dataset clearly outperforms the satellite-based radiation products at both daily and monthly scales. Averaged over all radiation stations and the time period of 1993–2010, the total RMSE values for daily global, direct and diffuse radiation are 23.2, 27.6 and 19.6 W m−2, respectively. At the monthly mean scale, our estimates give RMSE values of about 13.4, 16.5 and 10.9 W m−2, respectively, for monthly global, direct and diffuse radiation. These error indicators on both daily and monthly scales are generally lower than those of the satellite radiation products, especially for global and direct radiation.

Definition.Question: What is meant by a 'station-based radiation dataset' in the context of solar radiation data collection?
Definition.Answer: A 'station-based radiation dataset' refers to a collection of solar radiation data that is estimated and recorded at ground-based weather stations. In this context, it involves the use of meteorological variables observed at these stations to estimate daily global, direct, and diffuse solar radiation using specific radiation models.

Definition.Question: What are the 'routine meteorological variables' used in developing solar radiation datasets?
Definition.Answer: The 'routine meteorological variables' used in developing solar radiation datasets include surface pressure, air temperature, relative humidity, horizontal visibility, and sunshine duration. These variables are crucial as inputs for the radiation estimation models employed to construct the radiation dataset at various weather stations.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for solar radiation using station-based models compare to satellite-based retrieval methods in terms of data accuracy and reliability?
Comparison.Answer: Station-based models, which use routine meteorological variables observed at weather stations, tend to provide more accurate and reliable solar radiation data at both daily and monthly scales compared to satellite-based retrieval methods. Satellite-based methods provide continuous spatiotemporal observations but often suffer from longer-term data consistency issues and generally higher uncertainty, especially for direct and diffuse radiation.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when using in situ measurements for solar radiation data collection compared to satellite observations?
Comparison.Answer: In situ measurements are limited by the uneven distribution of radiation observation stations and high maintenance costs, resulting in sparse data coverage, especially in complex-terrain areas. In contrast, satellite observations provide broader spatiotemporal coverage but face challenges such as shorter time series, inconsistencies due to sensor updates, and higher algorithmic uncertainties, particularly for direct and diffuse radiation.

Comparison.Question: How do the long-term data availability and component inclusion (global, direct, diffuse radiation) differ between datasets constructed from station-based models and those derived from satellite data?
Comparison.Answer: Station-based datasets offer long-term data availability, often exceeding 60 years, and include global, direct, and diffuse radiation components. Conversely, satellite-derived datasets typically have shorter time series and primarily focus on global radiation, lacking detailed components like direct and diffuse radiation due to higher estimation uncertainties.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges can be inferred from the reliance on meteorological variables for estimating solar radiation data in complex-terrain areas?
Interpretation.Answer: The reliance on meteorological variables for estimating solar radiation data in complex-terrain areas can present challenges due to the uneven distribution of radiation observation stations, which are more densely located in flat, populated areas. Additionally, the accuracy of radiation measurements can be compromised due to problems and unreliable data, further exacerbating the difficulty in obtaining consistent and reliable solar radiation data in these regions.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of satellite data with ground-based observations improve the estimation of long-term solar radiation datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of satellite data with ground-based observations could potentially improve the estimation of long-term solar radiation datasets by providing continuous spatiotemporal observations that fill gaps in ground-based measurements. However, challenges such as inconsistent data quality due to sensor updates and multi-source data fusion need to be addressed to minimize uncertainties in long-term variation analysis.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in maintaining long-term and dense solar radiation observations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in maintaining long-term and dense solar radiation observations arise from the high maintenance and calibration costs associated with radiation observation stations, their uneven distribution, and the presence of erroneous or spurious data in radiation measurements.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it difficult to achieve consistent data quality in satellite radiation products for long-term analysis?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Achieving consistent data quality in satellite radiation products is difficult due to the changing technology of satellite sensors and the fusion of multi-source satellites, which introduce large uncertainties and inconsistencies in data quality for long-term analysis.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons behind the superiority of station-based radiation datasets over satellite-based products on daily and monthly scales?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Station-based radiation datasets outperform satellite-based products due to their higher accuracy on daily and monthly scales, as evidenced by lower RMSE values for global, direct, and diffuse radiation, which are especially significant in comparison to satellite-based radiation products.

Causal Consequence.Question: What might be the impact on data reliability when collecting solar radiation data in areas with varying terrain complexity and population density?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The impact on data reliability in areas with varying terrain complexity and population density can be significant, as radiation observation stations are unevenly distributed. Most are located in flat, densely populated areas, leading to potential data gaps and reliability issues in complex or sparsely populated areas.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might satellite-based radiation data products influence the long-term analysis of climate change if they do not include direct and diffuse radiation components?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Satellite-based radiation data products that do not include direct and diffuse radiation components may introduce large uncertainties in long-term climate change analysis. This is because global radiation alone does not account for the full range of solar radiation interactions with the Earth's surface, which can affect the accuracy of climate models and simulations.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the underlying goals of developing a long-term, high-accuracy dataset of daily surface solar radiation using surface radiation models?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to contribute to climate change research and solar energy engineering applications by providing a dense, station-based dataset that helps in simulations of land surface processes, climate change analysis, and solar energy applications. This dataset aids in assessing solar energy potential, optimizing solar PV panel angles, and analyzing long-term variations and historical extreme events in solar energy systems.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the motivations for utilizing both satellite and ground-based methods to estimate daily global, direct, and diffuse radiation in data collection?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The motivation is to overcome the limitations of each method by combining their strengths. Ground-based methods provide high-accuracy data but are limited by the sparse distribution and high costs of maintenance, while satellite methods offer continuous spatiotemporal observations but lack long-term consistency and accuracy in direct and diffuse radiation estimates. Utilizing both methods allows for a more robust and comprehensive dataset that can better support various research and application needs.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are utilized to estimate daily global, direct, and diffuse solar radiation in a station-based dataset, and how do they address the challenges associated with uneven distribution of radiation observation stations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The methodologies used involve the hybrid model developed by Yang et al. (2006) for global radiation and the method by Tang et al. (2018) for direct radiation. Daily diffuse radiation is then calculated by subtracting direct radiation from global radiation. These methodologies help address the challenge of uneven distribution of radiation observation stations by providing a systematic approach to estimate radiation using routine meteorological variables observed at 2743 China Meteorological Administration weather stations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can routine meteorological variables be leveraged to construct a long-term dataset of surface solar radiation, and what are the main inputs required for this data collection process?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Routine meteorological variables such as surface pressure, air temperature, relative humidity, horizontal visibility, and sunshine duration are leveraged to construct a long-term dataset of surface solar radiation. These variables are observed at 2743 CMA weather stations and serve as the main inputs needed for the development of the dataset, which spans over 60 years.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in validating a station-based solar radiation dataset against in situ observations, and how does this validation compare with satellite-based radiation products?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps for validation involve comparing the station-based radiation dataset against in situ observations and conducting comparisons with two satellite-based radiation products. The validation shows that the station-based dataset outperforms satellite-based products at both daily and monthly scales, with lower RMSE values for global, direct, and diffuse radiation, indicating higher accuracy.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable the construction of a long-term, high-accuracy dataset of daily surface solar radiation using existing meteorological observations?
Enablement.Answer: The construction of such a dataset is enabled by utilizing two surface radiation models: the global radiation estimation model by Yang et al. (2006) and the direct radiation estimation model by Tang et al. (2018). These models use routine meteorological variables like surface pressure, air temperature, relative humidity, horizontal visibility, and sunshine duration, observed at weather stations, to estimate daily global, direct, and diffuse radiation.

Enablement.Question: Which resources are crucial for enabling the development of a high-density solar radiation dataset over a long time period?
Enablement.Answer: Crucial resources for developing this dataset include the observational data from 2743 China Meteorological Administration (CMA) weather stations, which provide consistent and long-term coverage of surface pressure, air temperature, relative humidity, horizontal visibility, and sunshine duration, enabling the development of a solar radiation dataset spanning over 60 years.

Expectation.Question: Why might the integration of satellite-based observations with station-based data sources be challenging in creating a comprehensive solar radiation dataset?
Expectation.Answer: The integration of satellite-based observations with station-based data sources can be challenging due to issues like inconsistent data quality, large uncertainties introduced by the fusion of multi-source satellites, and the limited ability of satellite products to provide direct and diffuse radiation due to algorithmic uncertainties.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected challenges in maintaining long-term and dense solar radiation datasets, particularly in areas with complex terrain?
Expectation.Answer: Maintaining long-term and dense solar radiation datasets in areas with complex terrain is challenging due to the uneven distribution of radiation observation stations, which are mostly located in flat and densely populated areas. Additionally, radiation measurements are prone to errors and unreliable data compared to other meteorological variables.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of using hybrid models for estimating daily global and direct solar radiation in terms of accuracy and reliability?
Judgmental.Answer: The hybrid models used for estimating daily global and direct solar radiation are considered highly effective as they show better performance in accuracy and reliability compared to satellite-based products. Validation with in situ observations shows lower RMSE values for daily and monthly scales, particularly for global and direct radiation.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges faced in collecting long-term and dense solar radiation data, and how might these challenges impact data accuracy and utility?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges in collecting long-term and dense solar radiation data include the uneven distribution of radiation observation stations and the susceptibility of radiation measurements to errors and unreliable data. These challenges can impact data accuracy and utility by introducing inconsistencies and uncertainties, especially in complex-terrain and sparsely populated areas.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about how meteorological variables like surface pressure and horizontal visibility contribute to estimating daily solar radiation.
Assertion.Answer: Meteorological variables such as surface pressure, air temperature, relative humidity, horizontal visibility, and sunshine duration are crucial inputs for estimating daily solar radiation. These variables are used in radiation models to calculate global, direct, and diffuse radiation by considering the atmospheric conditions that affect solar radiation reaching the Earth's surface.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand why satellite-based radiation products have limitations compared to station-based datasets.
Assertion.Answer: Satellite-based radiation products often face limitations such as not having a long enough time series to meet the demand for climate change studies, inconsistent data quality due to sensor updates and multi-source fusion, and higher uncertainty in estimating direct and diffuse radiation compared to global radiation. In contrast, station-based datasets developed using hybrid models can provide more accurate and reliable data over long periods.

Assertion.Question: I’m confused about the challenges faced in ensuring the reliability of radiation data collected from ground stations.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges in ensuring the reliability of radiation data from ground stations include the uneven distribution of radiation observation stations, with most located in flat, densely populated areas, and fewer in complex terrains. Additionally, radiation measurements are prone to errors and unreliable data due to high maintenance and calibration costs, leading to issues such as erroneous or spurious data in the observations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the methods used for estimating daily global, direct, and diffuse radiation and evaluate their effectiveness.
Request/Directive.Answer: The methods used for estimating daily global, direct, and diffuse radiation involve two hybrid models. The global and direct radiation estimates are generated using the models by Yang et al. (2006) and Tang et al. (2018), respectively. The diffuse radiation is calculated by subtracting direct radiation from global radiation. The effectiveness of these methods is demonstrated by their performance in validation against in situ observations and comparisons with satellite-based products, showing that the station-based dataset outperforms satellite products at both daily and monthly scales, with lower RMSE values.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential sources or strategies for expanding or refining the availability of solar radiation datasets in regions with limited observational stations.
Request/Directive.Answer: Expanding or refining solar radiation datasets in regions with limited observational stations can involve increasing the use of satellite remote sensing to fill gaps in ground-based measurements, employing hybrid models that utilize routine meteorological variables such as surface pressure, air temperature, relative humidity, horizontal visibility, and sunshine duration, and integrating data from multiple satellites to enhance temporal and spatial coverage. Additionally, improving the algorithms for estimating direct and diffuse radiation can help in refining the dataset quality.
